docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Scant Progress on Closing Gap in Women's Pay'' (front page, Dec. 24): Why do women earn so much less than men? Because employers pay women so much less. Why? Because they can.

headline.main: Why the Pay Gap Persists for Women

docs.abstract: Four letters comment on Dec 24 article on gender pay gap; Ellen Bravo says it is time to close pay gap by fixing underlying problems such as undervaluing of women's work; Prof Norval D Glenn says one reason for unequal pay is that couples in dual-career marriages tend to give priority to his career over hers; Nathaniel L Schwalb says way of measuring gender wage gap can be misleading; Dr Helen Feit discusses gender pay gap among doctors
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Scant Progress on Closing Gap in Women's Pay'' (front page, Dec. 24):     Why do women earn so much less than men? Because employers pay women so much less. Why? Because they can.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE rich are getting richer, while most families in the region's suburbs have been losing economic ground since 1999. The suburbs are becoming increasingly diverse as Asian and Hispanic immigrants bypass New York City, traditionally the first stop for new arrivals.

headline.main: The Changing Face of the Suburbs

docs.abstract: Article on changes in New York City metropolitan area suburbs over past five years as they become increasingly diverse; analysis of Census Bureau data and other demographic information shows region is undergoing significant demographic change; median household income in most areas has dropped, job growth has slowed, employers seem to be having hard time finding younger workers and migration from region to exurbs, especially among young families, has increased as cost of housing continues to rise; number of people in region older than 75 has swelled by 10 percent, raising major concerns about availability and costs of health care, housing and other services for elderly; racial and ethnic makeup is changing rapidly, as white population shrinks and minority groups grow; drawing; photo; graphs; map (L)
docs.snippet: THE rich are getting richer, while most families in the region's suburbs have been losing economic ground since 1999.     The suburbs are becoming increasingly diverse as Asian and Hispanic immigrants bypass New York City, traditionally the first...

docs.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE CAREERS FUND OF WESTCHESTER is a small nonprofit group that helps disadvantaged youths from Port Chester, New Rochelle and White Plains get into college. This year, it received a $10,000 grant from the New York State Senate, and for that, it could consider itself lucky. The Senate has handed out more than 7,000 grants totaling $67 million this fiscal year, but only a handful went to groups in the part of Westchester where College Careers does its work.

headline.main: Scraping the Bottom of the Albany Pork Barrel

docs.abstract: Article compares pork barrel spending for fiscal 2006-7 by New York State Sen Cesar Trunzo, Republican from Suffolk County, with State Sen Suzi Oppenheimer, Democrat from Westchester County; while Trunzo has distributed $2 million in member grants, Oppenheimer's total was $230,000; list; photos (M)

headline.print_headline: Treatment Plans For Mentally Ill Kids

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Parenting as Therapy for Child's Mental Disorder'' (front page, Dec. 22):

headline.main: Treatment Plans For Mentally Ill Kids

docs.abstract: Letters from American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry pres Thomas F Anders and Sue Matorin respond to Dec 22 article about mentally ill children; Anders holds that academy does not 'strongly favor drug treatment'; Matorin applauds article for highlighting invaluable role parents can play to heal their troubled children
